questions.text: A 25 year rickshaw puller presents with daily headaches and multiple episodes of focal seizures. MRI head is shown below. Which of the following is first line intervention in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Dexamethasone 

MRI head shows a single ring-enhancing lesion in the right parietal lobe. It shows central hypointensity with peripheral rim enhancement. The perilesional edema is causing mass effect and slight effacement of nearby sulci. To control the seizures the first intervention would be dexamethasone that will reduce the vasogenic cerebral edema. Subsequently albendazole will be started. 

Stages of NCC

1. Vesicular: Cystic lesions with scolex.

2. Colloidal: Cysts degenerate, causing surrounding oedema. This is the stage seen in the image 

3. Granulonodular: Cysts with less oedema, more solidified 

4. Nodular-Calcified: Parasite is no longer viable. Cysts calcify, with no active inflammation.

questions.text: 30 year old man presented with high grade fever, headache and vomitting for past 5 days. MRI head shows double rim sign in left temporal lobe . Guided aspiration from lesion shows gram positive filamentous bacteria stained with a positive modified ZN staining and paraffin bait technique. What is the likely organism causing this?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Nocardia 

Double rim sign on MRI is a specific imaging feature of brain abscesses. The clinical features of headache and vomitting are explained by raised ICP and vasogenic cerebral edema seen in this patient. 

Gram-positive filamentous bacteria that are acid-fast with modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining strongly suggest Nocardia.

The paraffin bait technique further supports Nocardia diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common brain tumour in childhood?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Pilocytic astrocytoma 

Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common brain tumour found in children. It is a slow-growing, low-grade (Grade 1) tumour that typically occurs in the cerebellum. Most tumors in children are located infratentorially.

The most common childhood malignant brain tumors:

  1. Medulloblastomas
  2. High-grade gliomas
  3. Ependymomas

Histopathology:

  • Microscopic Features: Long, thin bipolar processes (pilocytic).
  • Key Pathological Findings: Rosenthal fibers, eosinophilic granular bodies.
  • Cellularity: Low-to-moderate, multinucleated giant cells.
  • Other Features: Hemosiderin-laden macrophages, calcifications (rare necrosis).
  • Infiltration: May infiltrate surrounding brain tissue.
  • Diagnosis: Challenging to differentiate from low-grade diffuse astrocytoma.

Immunohistochemistry: Positive for GFAP, S100, OLIG2; negative for neurofilament, chromogranin, CD34.

Histopathology of Pilocytic astrocytoma

questions.text: A 40 year old man with a known brain tumour has recently undergone radiation therapy. During a follow-up visit, his doctor ordered imaging studies to evaluate the tumour. The physician wants to determine whether the changes observed on the imaging are due to tumour progression or necrosis resulting from treatment. Which imaging technique can help differentiate between the two?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C) MR spectroscopy 

MR Spectroscopy provides insights into the chemical composition of the tissue, helping to distinguish between tumour progression and necrosis due to treatment. 

Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (MRS) is more specific than PET-CT in differentiating radiation necrosis from tumour recurrence, because:

  1. MRS detects elevated lipid-lactate peaks in necrosis (due to cell membrane breakdown).

  2. Tumour recurrence shows elevated choline (marker of cell membrane turnover).

Hence, MRS is preferred when available for metabolic fingerprinting of lesions post-radiotherapy.

Positron Emission Tomography -CT is a close second answer as tumor recurrence will show increased FDG uptake and radiation necrosis will show reduced FDG uptake. However it is less reliable in post-radiation brain lesions because normal brain tissue has high FDG uptake, which reduces contrast and makes it difficult to differentiate tumour recurrence from normal.

questions.text: 75-year-old male presents with recent onset frontal headache and seizures. Fundus reveals papilledema. MRI brain reveals a ring-enhancing lesion in the right frontal lobe with surrounding edema. MR Spectroscopy shows a high choline peak, low N-acetylaspartate (NAA), and elevated lipid-lactate peaks. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is  C: Brain tumor 

Geriatic patient with recent onset headache and papilledema indicates intracranial space occupying lesion.

Tuberculoma shows prominent lipid peak, no amino acids and less choline rise while our case has high choline. Plus there is no history of fever, weight loss or meningeal signs.  

Brain abscess causes causes very high-grade fever, toxic appearance which is not seen here. MRS shows amino acid peaks + lactate + restricted diffusion

NCC causes can show lipid peak ( only if degenerating cysts) but choline and NAA are reduced or absent. 

Brain tumor like GBM shows high choline ( due to high cell turnover and is the key word for this case presentation), low NAA,( due to neuronal destruction)  high lipid-lactate ( due to necrosis) and  abnormal perilesional MRS.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements on CNS tumours 


	Calcifications are found in Meningioma and Oligodendroglioma
	Craniopharyngioma are present as suprasellar mass
	Giant cell Astrocytoma and Ependymoma occur as Intraventricular tumours 
	Metastatic lesions occur at white matter-gray matter junction
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D) 1,2,3,4 

Intracranial calification is seen in meningioma, oligodendroglioma and craniophyrangioma. Craniophyrangioma is an supra sellar mass causing bitemporal hemianopia. Option C is solved by english as ependyma lines the ventricles. The usual source of metastasis to brain is oat cell cancer of lung that presents at gray and white matter interface. The metastatic cells can get trapped in the smaller blood vessels at the gray-white matter interface.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common primary malignant brain tumour in adults?

choices.text: Metastasis from oat cell cancer of lung

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Glioma 

Gliomas are the most common primary malignant brain tumours, with Grade IV glioma ( formerly called glioblastoma multiforme) being the most aggressive subtype 

  • Overall the most common brain tumour: Metastasis
    1. Small cell cancer of lung/ oat cell cancer
    2. Breast cancer
    3. Malignant melanoma
    4. Prostate Cancer 
  • Most common primary benign cancer is meningioma (shows intracranial calcification)

questions.text: A 30  year female presents with repeated episodes of GTCS since last 3 months. Neuroimaging is shown below. Which of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A:Valproate

Diagnosis is NCC and single calcified cyst is seen. Since this is end stage of parasite life cycle, there is no need for any cysticidal therapy. Since there is no vasogenic cererbral edema steroids are not required.  Anti epileptic drugs will be required for atleast 2 years. 

Treatment for NCC Stage wise 

  1. Vesicular (Viable) : Albendazole (± praziquantel for heavy/multiple or subarachnoid disease) with steroids.
  2. Colloidal (degenerating, inflammatory): Commonly treated with albendazole + steroids to hasten resolution and reduce seizure recurrence.
  3. Granular–nodular : Parasite largely dead; many guidelines do not routinely give anti-helminthics.
  4. Calcified: No anti-helminthic, no steroids; manage seizures only.
  5. Operative indication for Hydrocephalus

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B) Tuberculoma

Brain Abscess (Option C): A brain abscess usually presents as a singular lesion and may not show the conglomerated appearance described. While it can cause focal neurological deficits and systemic symptoms, it is less likely to present with the combination of signs of meningitis and multiple large lesions.

questions.text: A 28 year old female presents with recurrent headaches and occasional seizures. Neuroimaging is done. Which stage of development of parasite is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A: Vesciular stage 

  • Neurocysticercosis is a parasitic infection of the central nervous system caused by the larvae of Taenia solium, presenting with seizures, headaches, and neurological deficits. Diagnosis is typically confirmed through imaging (CT or MRI) showing cystic lesions, often with visible scolex, and supported by serological tests.
  • The vesicular Stage is characterized by cystic lesions containing a visible scolex, often described as having a "hole-with-dot" appearance on MRI. There is no significant surrounding oedema or abnormal enhancement on gadolinium-enhanced MRI, which aligns with the findings described in the clinical scenario.

 

MRI (Gadolinium-Enhanced) Features in Neurocysticercosis:

Gadolinium-enhanced MRI is crucial for identifying and differentiating between the stages of neurocysticercosis.

Vesicular Stage: (Live stage)

  • Cystic lesions with a visible scolex ("hole-with-dot" appearance).
  • No significant surrounding oedema or abnormal enhancement on gadolinium-enhanced MRI.

Colloidal Stage: (Degenerating stage)

  • Lesions show peripheral ring enhancement after gadolinium contrast administration. (Option B ruled out)
  • Substantial surrounding oedema is visible, particularly on T2-weighted images.

Granulonodular Stage: (Degenerating stage)

  • Lesions exhibit homogeneous enhancement on post-contrast MRI. (Option C ruled out)
  • No surrounding oedema is present, as seen on FLAIR images.

Nodular-Calcified Stage: (Dead stage)

  • No significant enhancement on gadolinium MRI. (Option D ruled out)
  • Calcifications are better seen with susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI), as they may not enhance well on standard MRI.

A: MRI of a vesicular cyst- Well-defined scolex, minimal contrast enhancement, and mass effect.

B: MRI of a colloidal cyst- Ring enhancement, loss of the scolex, and perilesional oedema.

C: MRI of the nodular/granular stage- Nodule with diffuse enhancement and no cystic component.

D: Noncontrast CT showing multiple punctuate calcifications.

questions.text: A 35 year old  male presents with multiple episodes of GTCS and persistent headaches. Neuroimaging of patient is shown. Which of the following tests will help in confirmation of diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Enzyme-Linked Immunotransfer Blot

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of GTCS, persistent headaches and neuroimaging showing several hypointense lesions with central white dot indicating scolex of developing larva are seen in Neurocysticercosis. Enzyme-Linked Immunotransfer Blot detects antibodies to Taenia solium antigens. It is a highly specific test and aids is confirmation of diagnosis. 

 

Investigation Modalities in Neurocysticercosis:

1. Gadolinium enhanced MRI 

  • Vesicular Stage: Cystic lesions are well-defined, often containing the scolex. (Live stage)
  • Colloidal: Ring enhancement, loss of the scolex, and perilesional oedema. (Degenerating stage)
  • Granulonodular Stages: Nodule with diffuse enhancement and no cystic component. (Degenerating stage)
  • Calcified Stage: Small hyperdense nodules (calcifications) are easily identified on CT without surrounding oedema or contrast enhancement. (Dead stage) 

.

2. Enzyme-Linked Immunotransfer Blot

  • Detects antibodies to Taenia solium antigens. It is highly specific. 

3. Fundoscopic Exam: To check for subretinal cysticerci

questions.text: A 50 year hypertensive man suddenly develops face, arm and leg weakness. Imaging confirms a large putaminal bleed. What type of brain herniation is most likely to occur in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Transtentorial herniation

A transtentorial herniation is the most common type of brain herniation and involves the medial temporal gyrus (uncus) being pushed through the tentorium cerebelli due to increased ICP.

Subfalcine herniation and cingulate herniation mean the same. It occurs when the cingulate gyrus is pushed under the falx cerebri., crossing the midline. 

in Foraminal herniation, cerebellar tonsils are forced downward through the foramen magnum, which can compress the brainstem and disrupt vital structures and occurs when LP is done in case of raised ICP . 

Features of Transtentorial herniation 

  1. Compression of the oculomotor nerve leading to ipsilateral pupillary dilation.
  2. Kernohan-Woltman sign: In some cases, the displaced brain tissue compresses the opposite cerebral peduncle against the tentorium, resulting in a Babinski sign and ipsilateral hemiparesis, a condition referred to as the Kernohan-Woltman sign.
  3. Brain infarctions: The anterior and posterior cerebral arteries can be compressed as they pass over the tentorium, potentially causing brain infarctions.
  4. Hydrocephalus: The herniation can block cerebrospinal fluid pathways, leading to ventricular entrapment and hydrocephalus.
  5. Coma

Different types of brain herniations

questions.text:
32 year man presents with recurrent seizures. MRI brain shows multiple hypointense lesions with scolex. What is the most likely cause of his condition?

1. Consumption of semi cooked pork containing Cysticerci cellulosae

2. Feco-oral 

3. Consumption of semi cooked beef  containing Cysticercus bovis

4. Autoinfection
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: 2,4 

 

Neurocysticercosis occurs when humans ingest T. solium eggs in contaminated food items like cabbage and lettuce.

The proglottids containing eggs are sticky and stick to peri-anal area. So autoinfection is also possible

Option wise analysis 

-Consumption of semi cooked pork containing cysticerci cellulosae: This leads to tapeworm (taeniasis/intestinal infection), NOT cysticercosis in humans

-Consumption of semi cooked beef containing cysticercus bovis: Irrelevant to the case; beef tapeworm (Taenia saginata) does not cause cysticercosis in humans.

 

Infection by adult Taenia solium tapeworms in the intestines (Option A): Intestinal infection with adult T. solium tapeworms causes taeniasis, not neurocysticercosis. Taeniasis occurs when humans eat undercooked pork containing larval cysts (cysticerci), which develop into adult tapeworms in the intestines. However, this form of infection does not lead to the formation of cysts in the brain or cause seizures.

 

Eating undercooked pork containing adult tapeworms (Option C): Eating undercooked pork exposes a person to larval cysts (cysticerci), not adult tapeworms. This leads to taeniasis, where the cysts mature into adult tapeworms in the intestines. This does not cause neurocysticercosis, as the infection of the brain occurs when eggs, not cysts, are ingested.


Migration of larvae from the lungs to the brain (Option D): The larvae of T. solium do not migrate from the lungs to the brain. After ingestion of eggs, the larvae penetrate the intestinal wall and travel through the bloodstream to reach various tissues, including the brain. The lungs are not involved in this migration process in neurocysticercosis.

questions.text: Elderly diabetic pateint living alone is found unconcious and unresponsive by the maid . On admission pulse is 100/min, BP =90/60 mm Hg. Work up shows RBS is 200 mg/dl, urine ketostix is 1+ , pH =7.42, pC02= 40 mm Hg, HCO3= 26 meq, Na = 130 meq/L and K= 4.0 meq/L and procalcitonin and CRP is normal . Which is next best step in managment of this patient?

choices.text: Start normal saline drip and urgent NCCT head
Start normal saline drip and insulin drip
Give bolus 10 units of regular insulin followed by insulin drip

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Start normal saline drip and urgent NCCT head

This unconcious unrepsonsive diabetic is hypotensive on admission with hyponatremia. Neuroimaging should be done to rule out stroke as cause of unconcious state. Fluids should be given to stabilize the BP.

DKA is ruled out as ABG is normal. Hyperosmolar coma is ruled out as blood sugar is 200 mg/dl only. CRP and procalcitonin is normal and rules out sepsis.

questions.text: A 50 year woman presents with seizure episode. She in ER she tells that she wakes up with daily early morning frontal headaches and vomiting. NCCT head shows intracranial space-occupying lesion in frontal lobe with dural tail sign. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer is B: II 

The patient is having a brain tumor/ meningioma based on radiological findings.  Raised ICP commonly leads to papilledema, which is swelling of the optic disc due to increased pressure transmitted via the cerebrospinal fluid around the optic nerve. So the answer will be optic nerve. Seizures in this patient can be explained by vasogenic cerebral edema seen with brain tumor. 

Overall the most common cranial nerve involved in raised ICP is the abducens nerve (CN VI), leading to lateral gaze difficulty (inability to move the eye outward)

questions.text: 38-year-old HIV-positive man presents with recurrent seizures and altered sensorium. MRI brain reveals multiple ring-enhancing lesions with perilesional edema in the basal ganglia and frontal lobe, showing the "concentric target" sign. What is the most likely cause of his seizures?
questions.solution:
Answer is A: Cerebral Toxoplasmosis 

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is the leading cause of multiple "concentric target" sign ring lesions in HIV patients, typically in basal ganglia or frontal lobes.

Primary CNS lymphoma usually appears as a solitary enhancing lesion, less often with target signs.

Neurocysticercosis shows cysts with scolex ("dot sign") rather than concentric targets. Tuberculoma may have ring enhancement but lacks the classic concentric target appearance seen in toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct component in brain death evaluation?

choices.text: Apnea test with pCO₂ rise to ≥60 mmHg or ≥20 mmHg above baseline
Pupils are fixed and non reactive to light
Absence of blinking on touching cornea with wisp of cotton

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Positive caloric stimulation 

A positive caloric test means the presence of nystagmus in response to cold or warm water irrigation of the ear, indicating an intact brainstem vestibulo-ocular reflex. In the context of brain death assessment, a positive caloric test is inconsistent with brain death, 

 

Brain Death Investigations

Brain death refers to the permanent cessation of all brain and brainstem functions while cardiac activity and other bodily functions are maintained artificially. It is legally and ethically equivalent to death.

Preconditions for Brain Death Testing
  • Deep coma with no influence of depressant drugs.
  • No hypothermia (body temperature >35°C).
  • Normal electrolyte, acid-base, and glucose levels, no metabolic or endocrine causes.
  • No spontaneous respiration due to ventilatory dependence.
  • The underlying condition causing brain damage must be irremediable.

Clinical Tests to Confirm Brain Death

Absence of brainstem reflexes:

  • Fixed, non-reactive pupils.
  • Absent corneal and vestibulo-ocular reflexes.
  • No motor response to cranial nerve stimulation.
  • Absent gag reflex and no response to tracheal suctioning.

Apnoea Test:

  • Checks for Spontaneous respiratory effort. 
  • There is no respiratory effort in brain death when disconnected from the ventilator, despite PaCO2 rising above 60 mmHg.

Additional Investigations

A four-vessel angiogram or isotope brain scan is used to confirm the absence of cerebral blood flow, particularly in complex cases.

Testing Protocol: Must be performed by two experienced doctors and repeated after a short interval to confirm the diagnosis. Once brain death is confirmed, organ donation may be considered with appropriate consent.

questions.text: 30-year-old biker is brought to the emergency room after a head injury. On examination, he is unconscious with an ipsilateral mid-dilated fixed pupil. NCCT head shows lenticular hyperdensity. Which of the following is the most likely cause and urgent next step?

choices.text: Uncal herniation due to epidural hematoma; immediate burr hole surgery required
Cingulate herniation due to epidural hematoma; immediate burr hole surgery required
Cingulate herniation due to epidural hematoma; urgent craniotomy
Subdural hematoma causing contralateral pupil dilation; urgent craniotomy

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Uncal herniation due to epidural hematoma; immediate burr hole surgery required

An ipsilateral mid-dilated fixed pupil following head trauma strongly suggests uncal herniation from an epidural hematoma causing compression of the third cranial nerve. This is a neurosurgical emergency requiring immediate surgical decompression, often by burr hole drainage. The other options either describe different injury patterns or pupillary findings that do not match the clinical picture requiring urgent burr hole surgery.

questions.text: Adult patient involved in a high-speed road traffic accident had a normal CT scan on admission but died within 6 hours. Autopsy reveals petechial hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and retraction balls. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Answer is A: Diffuse axonal injury 

Diffuse axonal injury occurs due to rapid acceleration-deceleration or rotational forces in high-impact trauma, causing shearing injury to the axons, especially in areas like the corpus callosum and brainstem.

The "retraction balls" represent swollen, broken ends of damaged axons, a hallmark microscopic finding in DAI.

Petechial hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and other white matter areas are caused by small vessel rupture during shearing injury.

Initial CT scans are often normal or show minimal findings despite severe injury, making early diagnosis challenging.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with TB meningitis exhibits develops posturing as shown in the diagram. Which of the following is correct about the cause of this presentation

choices.text: Inhibition of the rubrospinal with overactivity of vestibulospinal and reticulospinal pathways
Stimulation of the rubrospinal tract with simultaneous facilitation of vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts
Intact or overactive rubrospinal tract with loss of extensor facilitation from vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts
Loss of rubrospinal tract activity with strong extensor inhibition from vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts

questions.solution:
Answer is A: Inibition of the rubrospinal with overactivity of vestibulospinal and reticulospinal pathways

Patient has extension in arms and legs seen in decerebrate posturing. Notice "E" alphabet for extension being repeated. 

The key issue is damage below the red nucleus in the brainstem, which affects the balance of motor pathways controlling flexor and extensor muscles.

Flexors in arms are controlled by Rubrospinal tract, originating from the red nucleus in the midbrain. These are the ones damaged in decerebrate posturing where damage is below the level of red nucleus. 

Extensor in arms and legs are controlled by Vestibulospinal tract and Pontine reticulospinal tract. These extensor pathways remain intact and become overactive due to loss of inhibitory/facilitatory input from the damaged flexor pathways.

Option C describes a lesion above the red nucleus, where rubrospinal activity is preserved and drives upper-limb flexion while extensors act on the legs — the hallmark of decorticate posturing. 

Option D is the opposite of decorticate mechanisms, with both rubrospinal and extensor systems suppressed, which would not result in a classical rigid posture but rather severe hypotonia.

Posturing

questions.text: 60-year-old hypertensive man is brought to ER with sudden onset right-sided weakness and aphasia. His BP is 190/100 mmHg. CT scan done 1 hour after admission shows putaminal bleed and midline shift. Which of the following is not useful for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: iv dexamethasone 

The patient is having hemorrhagic stroke with midline shift. Both BP control to <140/90 mm Hg and mannitol for midline shift are required in this case. Ventriculostomy would be the most efficient step to control raised ICP in this patient. There is no role steroids in this case. Steroids are used in case of vasogenic cerebral edema while stroke patient will have cytotoxic cerebral edema.

questions.text: A 35 year old biker male is brought to the ED after a road traffic accident. He is unconscious with a GCS score of 9/15. Vitals are Pulse 60/min with BP: 160/100 mmHg  and irregular respiration. What is the first step in managing of this patient?

choices.text: Elevate head end of bed and secure airway

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Elevate head end of bed and secure airway

The patient shows signs of raised intracranial pressure , including a low GCS value and cushing triad.. The first step in managing raised ICP is to elevate the head end of the bed to 30 degrees and secure airway. This simple, non-invasive measure helps facilitate venous drainage from the brain, reducing intracranial pressure without compromising cerebral perfusion.

Mnemonic for Initial Raised ICP Management:"HEADS UP"

  • Head elevation (30°)

  • Ensure Airway (intubate if GCS <8)

  • Avoid hypotension/hypoxia

  • Drugs like mannitol (after airway secured)

  • Scan (CT brain)

  • Urgent neurosurgical referral

  • PaCO₂ control (hyperventilation if signs of herniation)
